column3: I'm sorry. I'm attending a meeting at the Hilton then.
column4: What about the next day?
column5: No. I'm busy then too. I'm meeting Dorothy Heath at North Bridge Road. Are you free on Thursday afternoon?
column6: Yes, I think I am. Let's meet for lunch at mouth restaurant.
column7: Good idea! Is two o'clock okay?
column8: That's fine. See you there!

column1: Is Bob home?
column2: Hold on

column1: Where are you planning on transferring to ;
column2: I can ’ t seem to make a decision.
column3: Where do you want to go?
column4: I honestly have no idea.
column5: You haven ’ t thought about it?
column6: I like it here at PCC.
column7: Why don ’ t you just continue going to PCC?
column8: I like that idea.
column9: It ’ s a great school.
column10: I completely agree.

column1: Pardon me. I need an old music box ;
column2: Exactly how old a box do you want?
column3: Actually, I was thinking about something from the 1920s.
column4: We still have six left.
column5: Do any of the boxes have dancing figures?
column6: Dancing figures are quite popular. Two of the boxes have them.
column7: I love the dancing figures. I'll take this music box.
column8: Yes, I think you'll be very satisfied with that one.
column9: I was wondering, does this come with any kind of warranty?
column10: No. But if something goes wrong with it, I know someone who repairs these things.

column1: How far do we have to go?
column2: About 50 miles.
column3: The traffic is not very heavy on this high way, is it? So I ’ m sure we ’ ll make it.
column4: No, but we ’ Ve got a hurry. It will be the rush hour soon.
column5: Don ’ t worry. There ’ s plenty of time yet.
column6: But it ’ s Friday today. This road is always jam packed during the weekend, isn ’ t it?
column7: Right.

column1: ( Having lunch with Joseph ) Have you ever been invited to a Chinese feast?
column2: Sure. Beijingers are distinguished for their warmth and hospitality.
column3: As far as you could see, is dining at a Chinese table a distinct experience? To what extent does it differ from that in your homeland?
column4: To begin with, I have to use chopsticks.
column5: But you look quite proficient in using them now.
column6: Certainly. After all, I've been here for two years. It's not much uphill work for a foreigner to get used to Chinese dinner utensils. Though, I do feel hazy about how to behave appropriately at a Chinese dinner table.
column7: Yes, table etiquette. There are a multitude of rules that foreigners might never know until they were told. Some practices even appear somewhat awkward or rude to Westerners, while they are the norm in China. Hey, your chopsticks, old silly! You should not stab them vertically into the rice bow!
column8: Anything strange about that?
column9: Maybe you should have placed them horizontally over your bowl or plate. They resemble two incense sticks used at sacrifices. It's very inauspicious, and might enrage all present.
column10: Oh, sorry! There's a long story even with a mere pair of sticks.

column1: Can you book me a double room for February 22?
column2: Well, we won't be able to guarantee you a room for February 22, but we can book you on February 23.Is that OK?
column3: I guess so.

column1: That was a great dinner. I didn't know that you knew how yo cook.
column2: I'm glad you liked it. Are you ready for dessert?
column3: I don't know. I'm pretty full. What are we having?
column4: I made strawberry shortcake.
column5: Ooh, that's my favorite. Maybe I'll have a small slice.
column6: Great. Would you like coffee or tea with that?
column7: I'll have a cup of tea.
column8: Do you take cream or sugar with your tea?
column9: Actually, could I have some milk with that?
column10: Definitely. Would you like skim or whole milk?
column11: Skim, please. That'd be very nice. Thanks... oh no. Janna, I'm so sorry, but I've got to go.
column12: What happened?
column13: I just got a message from my sister saying that she's been in a car accident. I need to go pick her up.
column14: I'll go with you. Where is she?
column15: She's on the M40, near Reading.
column16: Is she alright?
column17: I don't know, she didn't say. I'm so sorry about this.
column18: Don't worry. Family comes first. Come on, let's go.
column19: Actually, I've only got a two-seater. I'll have to go on my own.
column20: Ok. Just call me if you need anything then.

column1: The Canada Day is on the 1st of July.
column2: What is its national anthem?
column3: The national anthem of Canada is' O Canada'.
column4: Can you sing the song?
column5: Yes, I could sing it when I was very young.

column1: Did you feed the puppies today?
column2: Yes, I have.
column3: That's good! Just make sure to bathe them later.
column4: No problem. I can do that for you.
column5: Thank you! You know they have to go to the vet on Saturday?
column6: I know. What time do they go?
column7: Their appointment is at eleven o'clock in the morning.
column8: Okay, I won't forget.

column1: Could you tell me the right time, please?
column2: Well, my watch says five past two, but it's no use relying on it, because it has been gaining and losing these last few days.
column3: You'll have to get it fixed.
column4: Yes, I will.

column1: George speaks Japanese better than Frank.
column2: Yet in writing, George has nothing on Frank.
column3: Therefore, I hope they could help each other and learn from each other.

column1: Look at these gorgeous paintings!
column2: They are beautiful.
column3: Why not take a picture?
column4: Of course. I will.

column1: What does your mother do, may I ask?
column2: My mother works in a company as an accountant.
column3: Is she busy?
column4: Not always, she's rather busy at the end of the year.

column1: How do you celebrate Thanksgiving in the US?
column2: Well, Thanksgiving is family event.So on Thanksgiving, family members will get together and enjoy a big Thanksgiving dinner. Kids will have lot of fun.
column3: Do you say prayers before dinner?
column4: Yes, we do. It is an exciting moment.
column5: What is the biggest fun for you on Thanksgiving?
column6: For me? The football games of course, I love football games.

column1: What do you need?
column2: I would like to check out a book.
column3: I ’ m going to need your library card.
column4: I don ’ t have a library card.
column5: Why don ’ t you apply for one right now?
column6: Sure. That would be great.
column7: Please fill out this application.
column8: Okay. Here you go.
column9: Now, sign your name on the back of the card.
column10: Here you go.
column11: Here ’ s your library card.
column12: Thanks. Now I ’ d like to check out this book.

column1: Which language do you speak?
column2: Well, I studied French at school, but I ’ Ve forgotten most of it. I learnt some Russian while I was studying there and now I study Spanish in evening classes. Do you speak Japanese at home with your pa
column3: Yes, I do. I ’ m learning Chinese now on the internet.
column4: How do you find studying a language on the internet?
column5: It ’ s not easy, particularly with listening and speaking, because sometimes the connection isn ’ t too good.
column6: I bet you find the character difficult to write!
column7: Actually, many of the characters are the same or very similar in both Chinese and Japanese, so they ’ re easy for me.
column8: So, you can read and write much better than you speak and understand other speakers, right?
column9: Yes. How are the Spanish classes going?
column10: In a way, it ’ s similar to your experience of learning Chinese. Some Spanish words are very similar to English ones. But I need to practise listening to native speakers and saying the words myself.

column1: Darling, I have news for you. Bobby and his wife, Evelyn, are going to have a baby soon.
column2: Really? I thought his wife couldn ’ t have a baby.
column3: Actually they ’ re expecting the baby to come on my birthday.
column4: Oh, what a coincidence! I bet Bobby must be very happy about it. He likes children and always wants a child of his own.
column5: In fact, they ’ re both very excited about the coming baby. Evelyn imagines what their baby would be look like, since one parent is American and the other one is Chinese.
column6: Oh, right. Now I know why they would want to see our boy. It ’ s hard to imagine the wonder! Are they expecting a boy or a girl?
column7: It ’ s still a mystery. Because Evelyn is only three-month pregnant. But she begins to take her maternity leave now.
column8: Oh! You mean she doesn ’ t have to work now? It ’ s hard for young parents not to overreact, isn ’ t it?

column1: How wonderful it is to be in love! It's love at first sight! Oh. he's my Romeo!
column2: Hey, Julie. How's it going?
column3: Oh, Mary. You've surprised me!
column4: Who were you talking to?
column5: Um — I was just thinking aloud.
column6: You look so happy. I see a twinkle in your eyes.
column7: Come off it, Mary.
column8: Oh, you have a crush on someone, don't you? Maybe those are wedding bells in your eyes!
column9: You certainly do like teasing me, Mary. Well I'm in love with someone. The question is, how do I get his attention?
column10: Well, that's easy. Walk up to him and kiss him.
column11: I guess I asked the wrong person.

column1: After you
column2: Thank you!
column3: What's the weather like in your country? I suppose it must be warmer than here.
column4: Oh, yes. We have rather mild winters. It always has much sunshine in winter. But it was very foggy when I left two days ago. I knew it would be colder here, but I thought there would be a lot of snow.
column5: We don't have much snow in winter in Beijing. In fact, we haven't had any so far this winter. The winter is rather long, but the cold is generally not severe. The temperature seldom gets as low as ten below zero Centigrade.
column6: What is the temperature today, do you know?
column7: About freezing point, I think.But the morning's forecast said that we are going to have a very cold spell in the next few days - and the temperature will probably drop to 10 or 15 degrees below zero.
column8: Oh, I'm very lucky that my wife let me take a heavy overcoat.
column9: It is considerate of your wife.
column10: Yes, she is. By the way, what is the best season in Beijing?
column11: Fall is the best season in Beijing. It's neither hot nor cold. The sky is clear and blue. There's hardly any wind, only a slight breeze which is hardly noticeable. And we have plenty of sunshine too.
column12: Really? Then I will come to Beijing in the fall next time.
column13: Good, you are welcome.

column1: Hello, is that the Peace Restaurant?
column2: Yes. May I help you?
column3: Yes. I'd like a table for six at 7:00 this evening. Can you arrange it for us?
column4: Just a minute. I'll check if there is any availability. I'm sorry, sir. There isn't any table left for 7:00, but we can give you one at 8: 00. Would you like to make a reservation at that time?
column5: Let me see. It seems a little late.
column6: Usually, the restaurant will be quieter at that time.
column7: OK. I'll change the time to 8: 00.
column8: Very good, sir. A table for 6 at 8: 00 this evening. May I have your name, please?
column9: It's John.
column10: Thank you very much. Bye.

column1: Who is your favorite NBA star?
column2: Kobe Bryant, of course.
column3: Kobe? I know him, the key guy of the Lakers, a heck of a NBA player. He is on fire when he breaks through enemy defense.
column4: He is competent both in driving the lane and shooting jumpers, but what really makes him formidable is his ability to switch up and dribble with his left hand.
column5: Maybe he is not good at rebounding?
column6: Indeed, no man can be perfect. He is just so-so in crashing the boards. Usually he plays shooting guard. Rebounding might not be his strong suit.
column7: Kobe came to Beijing during this summer's Olympics. Did you go to the match between China and USA?
column8: Who wouldn't! My friend Lee went so far as to get an autograph from him.
column9: Well then, what are your spoils?
column10: Well, nothing more than a jumble of photographs.

column1: Hello everyone, and welcome to our CPR for beginners course. First of all, does anyone know what CPR stands for?
column2: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation!
column3: That ’ s right! We apply CPR in the case of cardiac arrest or pulmonary arrest.
column4: What does that mean?
column5: Well, basically if your heart stops pumping blood, or your lungs stop pumping air, then we need to get them going again! That ’ s when we have to apply this procedure. Let ’ s begin! I need a volunteer.
column6: Me! Me!
column7: Alright, come here and lay flat on your back. Let ’ s suppose this young woman has stopped breathing. We must lift the person ’ s chin so that we clear a pathway for air to get into the lungs. Then we place our mouth over the other person ’ s mouth and blow air two or three times, like this.
column8: Wait, what are you doing? I ’ m a married woman! You can ’ t just try to kiss me like this!
column9: Madam I ’ m not trying to kiss you! I am trying to demonstrate how to apply CPR in the case of an emergency.
column10: Well, OK. But no French kissing!
column11: As I was saying, we blow air through the mouth in this manner. Once this is done, we must try to get the heart going again. To do this, we place our hands over the person ’ s chest, and press down firmly two or three times.
column12: Wait, what are you doing! You can ’ t just kiss me then go for second base!

column1: Which aisle has the produce?
column2: Aisle A is where you'll find all the produce.
column3: Are cherries on sale today?
column4: I don't know, but I'm sure the produce person can tell you.

column1: What day is it?
column2: It's Monday, October 27. Speaking of dates, when are you leaving?
column3: I'm leaving on November 10th.
column4: Isn't it a Sunday?
column5: No, it's a Monday.
column6: So you are leaving two weeks from now?
column7: Right.

column1: What was the biggest turing point in your life?
column2: I usee I would say that would be moving out of my parents ’ house for the first time.
column3: Really? Why is that?
column4: Till I moved out of my parents ’ home, I became a lot more independent.
column5: What would you say was the lowest point in your life?
column6: That would definitely be getting a divorce.
column7: What went wrong?
column8: We just weren't right for each other.
column9: How long were you married?
column10: The marriage only lasted about a year.
column11: Have you remarried since then?
column12: Yes, I got married to a man that I met shortly after I divorced my first husband.
column13: Do you think you'll ever get a divorce again?
column14: Oh I hope not, my first marriage was a mistake, but this one isn ’ t.
column15: How long have you been married?
column16: About 15 years now.
column17: Do you think you'll still love him when he is old and gray?
column18: I think so, hopefully we ’ ll have a long and a happy life together.
column19: I ’ m sure you will.

column1: Hello. What can I do for you, sir?
column2: Hi. Fill it up please. Premium.
column3: Sure.
column4: Oh, can you check my oil and tires while you're at it?
column5: No problem. I'm gonna need you to turn off your engine and open the hood for me.
column6: OK, it's open.
column7: Your oil is fine but your tires are a little flat.
column8: Oh. Where can I add some air to my tires?
column9: Right here. I'll do it for you. ( Three minutes later ) Your car's ready.
column10: Good. How much does it come to?
column11: Nine gallons of premium. That's $ 15.32, please.

column1: You didn ’ t show up in the morning meeting. What ’ s up?
column2: Well, I just came in. I worked overtime yesterday. Some statistics and very important documents seemed to be inaccurate. So I stayed to double check them. The boss was aware of my very late work of last night. So before he left office, he told me I could come one hour later this morning.
column3: But you still look a little bit tired. What time did you leave?
column4: It was around one thirty in the morning. I guess I didn ’ t fall asleep till 3 because those numbers were involving in my mind. I just couldn ’ t stop thinking about them.
column5: That ’ s normal after a tense work evening. Working overtime is not always a pleasant experience for me either. Once, I worked overtime everyday for a whole week including the weekend. That really broke my rhythm and I got a little sick later.
column6: Working at weekend is something I hate to do most.
column7: But if the company asks, what else can we do?

column1: You honestly believe the world ’ s improving every year?
column2: Yes, I do. I think that science is making us wiser. What do you think?
column3: I don ’ t think you ’ re right there.
column4: I believe industry is making us wealthier.
column5: I don ’ t believe that.
column6: And in my opinion, medicine is making us healthier.
column7: I agree with you in the sense. But we ’ re all more miserable than ever, aren ’ t we?
column8: I don ’ t agree with you. I maintain that we ’ re healthier, wealthier and wiser than we were a hundred years ago.
column9: That ’ s your opinion not mine.

column1: Mr. : For tomorrow, read pages 12 to 20. Then do exercises one through ten on page 21.
column2: Do we have to type out our homework?
column3: Mr. : No. You only do that when you write reports.
column4: Is there anything else?
column5: Mr. : For those of you who don't have a calculator, get one.
column6: We are allowed to use a calculator in class?
column7: Mr. : Yes. By the way, review today's notes this evening. We may have a small quiz tomorrow.

column1: You'll have to take a make-up exam in logic.
column2: Oh, I thought I did a good job.
column3: Sorry to say you failed.
column4: Anyway, I have to face the music this time.

column1: John, if you don't mind, I'd like to ask you a personal question.
column2: I don't mind at all.
column3: All right.Are you married?
column4: To tell you the truth, I'm not married. I'm still single.
column5: Then, when do you plan to get married?
column6: I don't know.It' s still up in tha air.

column1: Mom, I don't feel well.
column2: Are you sick?
column3: I feel dizzy.
column4: Let me take your temperature.
column5: Mom, I don't want to go to see a doctor.
column6: Oh, honey, I think you've caught a cold, you should get a shot.

column1: Wow, American football is more exciting than I thought.
column2: You ’ re in America now, my British friend. We just call it football.
column3: Oh, right. So, I can ’ t quite follow what ’ s going on... who ’ s winning?
column4: The Giants are up by three points because of the field goal they kicked, but the Redskins have the ball and there pretty close to the end zone.
column5: Wow! What a hit!
column6: Yeah, he tackled him so hard his helmet came off.
column7: Is he ok?
column8: It looks like it, he ’ s getting up.
column9: I guess he hit him too hard ; the referee just called a penalty on the home team.
column10: The Giants?
column11: Yeah.
column12: Well, here we go again.
column13: What happened? Why did everyone get so quiet?
column14: The Redskin ’ s quarterback just threw a touchdown pass for seven points. We ’ re losing again.

column1: I heard that ben is forming his own band.
column2: It will be a rock and roll band probably. He ’ s a very good guitarist.
column3: Can you play a musical instrument? If you can, he might ask you to join the band.
column4: I can play drums, but I haven ’ t played for a while. I ’ m not sure I ’ d be good enough to play in a band.
column5: I wish I could play a musical instrument. I love music.
column6: Nowadays, you can be a DJ. You can mix dance music. You don't need to be able to play music instrument or thing.
column7: I love to try it, but the instrument is expensive and it was still need to take a lot of practice.
column8: You know, you could probably get a computer program that would help you. You already have a computer, so you could use that to help you mix some music.
column9: That ’ s a great idea. I ’ ll search for some information on the internet. If it ’ s possible to do, the internet will have some information about it.

column1: Well, how did you enjoy your seaside trip?
column2: It was funny.
column3: Tell me about it, will you?
column4: Well, we drove through the valley on our way there in the morning. It was a magnificent sight.
column5: Did you stop at the big waterfall for pictures?
column6: Sure, we wouldn't miss it for anything. After that, we took a short cut to the park. There was very little traffic, so we got there in less than an hour.
column7: You were lucky then. What did you do after that?
column8: We went for a swim in the sea. That was the best part of the day. Just look at my nice tan.
column9: So you must have had a busy and enjoyable day yesterday.
column10: Yes, you're right. And I was so tired that I fell asleep on the way back. My arms are still stiff from the swim yesterday.

column1: You look pale, you must have poor health.
column2: Yeah. You said it.
column3: Why not go to see the doctor?
column4: I ’ Ve done that. The doctor advised me to cut out smoking and drinking.

column1: Are you sure this is the right restaurant 。
column2: Positive 。
column3: You don't think you could be wrong?
column4: I'am absolutely sure I'm right.
column5: I don't know. It looks a little wrong down.
column6: This is right. There is no doubt in my mind.
column7: You're hundred percent sure you want to eat here?
column8: Check and double check.

column1: I am tired of everything in my life.
column2: What? How happy you life is! I do envy you.
column3: You don ’ t know that I have been over-protected by my mother these years. I am really about to leave the family and spread my wings.
column4: Maybe you are right.

column1: Are you through with your meal?
column2: Yes, we are. Could we have the check please?
column3: Here you go. I can take care of it here when you are already.
column4: Do you accept checks?
column5: No, I'm sorry we don't. We accept credit cards and cash.
column6: Well, I don't have any cash with me, I'll have to put it on a credit.
column7: Thank you, I'll be right back. Do you need any to go boxes? I'd be glad to bring you some when I come back.
column8: Yes, we do, thank you.

column1: Egg, this bathroom is a pigsty!
column2: Helen, why do you keep flushing the toilet? What's wrong?
column3: I just can't stand it. It's really gross in here! There' s a stain on the toilet seat, and the floor was wet and slippery. So I cleaned it!
column4: You did what? Helen, I know it's gross, but I' Ve seen many public washrooms that are much worse. Why are you cleaning the counter top? are you out of your mind?
column5: I can't help myself ; it's just so disgusting in here!
column6: Helen, this is not like your own bathroom. Just leave it to the cleaners, okay?
column7: Hang on. I'm just gonna quickly wipe the sink and sweep the floor.
column8: You're such a neat freak! I'm outta here!

column1: Is there anything I can do for you?
column2: I'm planning a trip to Europe.
column3: Have you decided which city you want to go?
column4: Well, what's the price of this route?
column5: That's $ 400 and we will visit 4 cities.

column1: You look really wiped out.
column2: I had meetings back to back all morning. Then the printer broke in the middle of putting together the Six Soap presentation, and the phone rang off the hook from the minute I walked into the office.
column3: Not a good day, I hate to tell you that Mr. Emory wants to see the designs for the Polish Paste Ad tomorrow morning.
column4: I can ’ t believe it! I guess I ’ ll be here until ten again tonight!

column1: Which sports are popular in your country?
column2: Most people like football. More boys like football than girls. A few girls play it really well. Some people like playing basketball.
column3: Do many people like tennis?
column4: More and more people like it now. fewer people play table tennis than before. Many people like swimming, because it is fun and keeps you fit.
column5: In my country, many people enjoy golf, but it is too expensive for some people. A few people like extreme sports, but I think the vast majority of people are afraid to try them.
column6: Extreme sports are only for a small minority of people. Several people from my university enjoy them, but most of us just watch. No one I know plays golf.
column7: I know loads of people who play it regularly. There are plenty of golf courses around the country. In the past, only a tiny number of people played.
column8: A great deal of people follow rugby in my country.
column9: There are plenty of rugby fans in my country too.

column1: You honestly believe the world ’ s improving every year?
column2: Yes, I do. I think that science is making us wiser. What do you think?
column3: I don ’ t think you ’ re right there.
column4: I believe industry is making us wealthier.
column5: I don ’ t believe that.
column6: And in my opinion, medicine is making us healthier.
column7: I agree with you in the sense. But we ’ re all more miserable than ever, aren ’ t we?
column8: I don ’ t agree with you. I maintain that we ’ re healthier, wealthier and wiser than we were a hundred years ago.
column9: That ’ s your opinion not mine.

column1: Wow, the view from the peak is so grand!
column2: Look, most of the maple leaves have turned red.
column3: Did you ever see this kind of beautiful scene?
column4: Of course, my father used to take me to Kiang Shan or somewhere like that as a child.
column5: But my father did not. He didn't have much time.
column6: Honey, I'm sorry. I promise you, this summer vacation, I will take you to Huang-Shan Mountains. It is more beautiful and magnificent.
column7: Really? It's a deal. Have you ever been there?
column8: Yes, I went there five years ago. You were still a baby at that time.
column9: It really gets me interested. Is it higher than Kiang Shan?
column10: Surely. You can enjoy the beauty of numerous streams and waterfalls. The sea of clouds has a fairy tale beauty.
column11: Can I see the rainbow?
column12: That depends. If you are lucky, you can see a vivid rainbow across over two peaks.

column1: Balista, I'll have a frappuccino.
column2: What a girly drink. I'll take a bag of the Blue Mountain and a decaf breva...
column3: You and your fancy Italian names.
column4: Isn't “ frappuccino ” Italian, too?... and heat me up a panini.
column5: I'll be fine with just my girly drink, thank you very much.
column6: And I'll stick with real coffee.

column1: It seems that you get antsy when you hear I praise another guy.
column2: I get antsy not because you praise a guy, but because you may be taken for a ride by a guy like him.
column3: How come you think of him that way?
column4: Because you seem to have lost your vigilance. You should be on the watch out.
column5: I have no reason to distrust him. He's never caused any harm.
column6: Isn't there anything that sounds fishy?
column7: Nothing smells a rat. I told you that he's an all-right guy.
column8: All-right guy? All right. Let's talk about something else instead.

column8: That's right.
column9: By the way, how do you like to pay for it? This hotel prefers cash.
column10: I see. When can I receive your confirmation?

column1: How can I tell her about this?
column2: Don't worry, you'll find a way.
column3: There is no need to be so frustrated.
column4: How can you live without job in the future?
column5: Don't worry, you'll find a way.

column1: Mary is really a diligent girl.
column2: What do you mean?
column3: She learns to speak Latin by osmosis within three months.
column4: She is really something.

column1: OK, Devon, I've been putting on a few pounds and you're quite a lean fit guy.
column2: Well, thank you.
column3: What do you recommend? What can I do to lose weight?
column4: Well, I exercise a lot. I go running at least three times a week. But more than that I enjoy playing sports and so different sports use different muscles and all of it helps to lose that weight that you might have gained.
column5: Yeah, well, actually, one of the problems is that I actually exercise a lot.
column6: Do ya?
column7: Yeah, so maybe it's my diet.
column8: It could be and so in that case you might want to eat something perhaps more nutritious or maybe even less of what you do eat. Maybe, I eat three meals a day and I try not to snack in between. No potato chips. No popcorn. No candy bars.
column9: That's pretty tough!

column1: Hello, Ann! Is that you ;
column2: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
column3: It's been a long time! What's new?
column4: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
column5: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
column6: How was it?
column7: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
column8: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
column9: Ok, I won't keep you then.
column10: Great! It's good to see you. Goodbye!

column1: David, why didn ’ t you clean the room?

column6: But she did and made me disappointed.
column7: Oh, cheer up. A girlfriend is not everything.
column8: But she means a lot to me.
column9: Then forgive her mistake.
column10: Oh. I just can ’ t forget it.

column4: I have no idea.

column6: But rose is too common.
column7: Well, what about violet? It means the eternal beauty.
column8: It looks good. Pack me a bouquet of violet, please.

column4: I don't know. She always said I didn't love her, but I did.

column6: I have asked for a talk again, but she refused and said she wanted to be quiet.
column7: Come on, guy. Maybe she isn't your right person.

column5: Oh, will you? That's too bad.We' re very sorry to cause you a lot of trouble.

column1: Do you like swimming?
column2: Yes. Swimming is one of my most favorite sports, indoors or out-doors.
column3: Me too. Swimming is a very good exercise for health. It combines water, bath, sunbath, and air bath together. It promotes the growth and haleness of muscles, bone, viscera and nerve systems.
column4: I have never thought that swimming can bring us so many benefits. I only know that swimming in great waves and deep running water can train people's spirits, and enable people to be fearless of the hardships, dangers and difficulties and become brave and staunch.
column5: Have you ever swum in a river or a lake?
column6: Yes, but not always. However, I won't let it go if I have a chance.

column7: How much does it cost?
column8: Let me see, with padding and lining cloth, it comes to 357 dollars altogether.
column9: All right. When can I get it?
column10: In two weeks.
column11: Thank you.

column1: that was a great party. Thanks for saying behind to help me clear up ;
column2: it certainly was a great party. It ’ s a pity that a glass and a plate got broken and someone spilled a drink over here.
column3: I expected that something might get broken. That doesn ’ t bother me. That spilled drink won ’ t leave a stain, will it?
column4: I doubt it, I ‘ ll deal with it right away. Luckily it wasn ’ t a glass of red wine, I ’ ll just get a bowl of water and a cloth.
column5: I ’ m going to put all the rubbish into this big plastic bag.
column6: afterwards, we can do the washing up together. Everything will be finished within an hour. Your friend Keith is really funny. I liked his magic tricks.
column7: yes, he ’ s very good.. isn ’ t he? He told some funny stories too.
column8: Amanda told some very funny jokes. At the beginning of the party, she was being ver serious.
column9: I think that she had a litter too much of the punch.
column10: what did you put in that punch? It tasted great, but was quite strong.

column1: Listen, Karen, I need your help. I don't know anyone here yet.
column2: I'm glad to help you. What's wrong?
column3: My mother-in-law just went into the hospital in L.A.Hank and I will be flying there tonight.
column4: I'm sorry to hear it. What's wrong with her?
column5: Doctors aren't sure yet.But the real problem is Suzy. She has a bad cold, and we don't want to take her with us. But we don't know who can stay with her.
column6: You need a babysitter.
column7: Yes, I'd ask Jill, the girl I've had before, but I need someone overnight.Maybe even for two nights.
column8: I could have Suzy stay at my place.
column9: I don't want to do that to you, Karen.
column10: Why not?
column11: Your own kids would get Suzy's cold. I think it would be better to have a good babysitter here. But I don't know who to ask. I need someone more mature than Jill. It might even be for two or three days.
column12: I know who we can ask. There is a girl I know, Sara Ralston.She is 17, and she will usually take this kind of job. I know her from my church, and I trust her completely.
column13: I'd like to talk with her.This is short notice, I know. But Hank and I are leaving tonight.
column14: I'll get you her number. I hope she can do it. She is very responsible.
column15: I'm glad you know someone. I knew you would be the best person to ask about this. I don't want to insult Jill or her mother. I think Jill maybe could do it.But I'd rather have someone a little older.
column16: I'll go home and get Sara's number. I'll call her first myself.
column17: Great. Then call me and let me know if she's free.

column1: Good afternoon, sir.
column2: Good afternoon. I have a reservation under the name of Hilton.
column3: Could you spell that, please?
column4: Sure. It's H-I-L-T-O-N.
column5: One moment, please. Ah yes, Mr. Hilton, you booked a single room for three nights. Is that correct?
column6: Yes, that's right.
column7: I see from the computer that you are a frequent guest here. Do you have your loyalty card?
column8: Yes, here you are. And here's my credit card, too.
column9: Thank you. Right, your room number is 105. Here's your key and receipt. Thank you for choosing our hotel again, sir.
column10: Thank you, goodbye.
column11: Goodbye.

I can recommend you some online merchants. Second, write your mail address correctly. Otherwise, you can ’ t receive your delivery in time.

column6: Not at all. You just need to provide your name, address, e-mail address, phone number and bank or credit card information. I will help you with that.

column4: Nothing that serious. She finally told them that she moved out of the dormitory a few months ago and has been living with her boyfriend.

column6: That's putting it mildly. My father started shouting at my sister and my mother just glared at her.

column8: She started arguing back to my dad that how much she loves her boyfriend, how they're in love and it's not hurting anybody, and so on. My dad said she's too young to do this, and that she should move out right away.
column9: How long has your sister been with her boyfriend?
column10: Three years. They've been dating since freshman year. They're even talking about marriage.

column9: I don't know exactly. It's a tradition. Maybe it's for sanitary reasons.

I heard this year, the government has imposed very stringent inspection on the hi-gene conditions restaurants and suppliers of food are also under tighter control. For sure all the customers will benefit from this.

column1: I ’ Ve had it! I ’ m done working for a company that is taking me nowhere!
column2: So what are you gonna do? Just quit?
column3: That ’ s exactly what I am going to do! I ’ Ve decided to create my own company! I ’ m going to write up a business plan, get some investors and start working for myself!
column4: Have you ever written up a business plan before?
column5: Well, no, it can ’ t be that hard! I mean, all you have to do is explain your business, how you are going to do things and that ’ s it, right?
column6: You couldn ’ t be more wrong! A well written business plan will include an executive summary which highlights the idea of the business in two pages or less. Then you need to describe your company with information such as what type of legal structure it has, history, etc.
column7: Well, that seems easy enough.
column8: Wait, there ’ s more! Then you need to introduce and describe your goods or services. What they are and how they are different from competitors ’? Then comes the hard part, a market analysis. You need to investigate and analyze hundreds of variables! You need to take into consideration socioeconomic factors from GDP per capita to how many children on average the population has! All this information is useful so that you can move on to your strategy and implementation stage, where you will describe in detail how you will actually execute your idea.
column9: Geez. Is that all?
column10: Almost, the most important piece of information for your investors will be the financial analysis. Here you will calculate and estimate sales, cash flow and profits. After all, people will want to know when they will begin to see a return on their investment!
column11: Umm. I think I ’ ll just stick to my old job and save myself all the hassle of trying to start up a business!

column7: Well, there are core courses and electives.
column8: What do they mean?
column9: Core courses are ones that you must take. Elective courses are ones that you get to choose for yourself.

column4: I didn ’ t know you were a twin! Are you identical or fraternal?
column5: We ’ re identical. I mean, we look exactly the same, but we are complete opposites when it comes to everything else.
column6: Interesting. It must be great having a twin sister. Are you best friends, too?
column7: We used to be really close, but that all changed once she moved to Shanghai. How about your family? You didn ’ t mention to your biological father.
column8: I don ’ t know much about him. He died when I was just a baby. Even though I don ’ t have a blood relationship with my step-father and step-brother, I consider them to be my real family.
column9: What about your step-brother ’ s mother? Does he keep in touch with her?
column10: No, she also died when my step-brother was little. My mother and my step-father met each other shortly after my father died and became good friends. They ended up getting married a few years later.

column1: Hello, this is Mike, Kara.
column2: Mike! Good to hear from you. How are you?
column3: Everything is fine, and how are you?
column4: Things are going well with me.
column5: Kara, I had fun the other night at the movies and was wondering if you would like to go out again this Friday.
column6: Mike, I don't think that it's a good idea to go out again. I really need to focus on getting packed and ready to move back home.
column7: Maybe we could just meet for coffee or something.
column8: I can't really deal with any distractions right now, but I appreciate the nice evening we spent together.

column1: Do you have much experience with kids?
column2: Yes. I have three sons. Actually I also have a grandson.
column3: To tell you the truth, sometimes I regret having a baby so early. I have been making so many sacrifices just because my husband insisted on keeping the baby.
column4: I understand. I was in your position before. At that time I couldn ’ t depend on anyone taking care of the children for me. My husband seldom stayed at home.
column5: What about your mother? Did she help you?
column6: Yes, she did a little. But you see, Americans are different from Chinese. You can ’ t depend on your own mother to be a full-time babysitter. She could baby-sit only once or twice a week. That ’ s it. I had to care for them most of the time.
column7: I see. So if my little family goes to America, I would end up taking care of my child all the time. My husband would have to make the bread for us. I just don ’ t know how I would get some education and be able to get a job some day.
column8: Don ’ t worry. You can take night classes. I did that when I had kids. And soon your child will be old enough to attend kindergarten. Then you could find a job and work.
column9: Sounds not so easy to me. When that happens, I will be too old to learn.
column10: No. You see, I went back to school to get my Master ’ s Degree when I was in my thirties. You won ’ t be older than that.

column1: Oh, hey, Keri! You cook, right! You're a pretty good cook ;
column2: I'm OK.
column3: OK. I want to make an omelet, so actually this is really silly, I've never made one before. How do you make an omelet?
column4: OK, Well, I can teach you how I make them, which is the same way my father and grandmother make them, which is a little special.
column5: OK. Yeah! Yeah!
column6: First you take some eggs and crack them in a bowl, and whisk them up, quite, so they're quite high and fluffy, and in a hot pan, and you need a pan that's that's kind of small, that the sides go up at an angle. You put some oil and heat it up, so it's quite hot, and then you take your whipped up eggs, or whisked up eggs, and pour them into the pan, and as it's cooking, if you take a spatula, and push the bottom layer of the egg, to the side, to the sides, and then to the middle, so the uncooked egg gets to the bottom of the pan.
column7: Oh, OK. Wow!
column8: OK. And keep doing that until most of the egg is cooked so you should have a nice thick omelet and then flip it over, you'll only have to cook that side lightly. Put your fillings on the top and fold it over and let it sit just long enough to melt the cheese.
column9: Wow. That sounds really good.
column10: Mm, it is.
