column1: Let ’ s play a little game. I ’ ll describe someone and you try to guess who it is.

column11: I like slim girls, so I doubt I would find a plump girl attractive. You ’ ll have to give me some more information.
column12: She ’ s got tiny feet and wears really unfashionable shoes. In fact, she wears unfashionable clothes too.

column15: How embarrassing! I don ’ t even recognize a description of my own mother! How important do you think appearance is?
column16: I think that unfortunately it ’ s more important than a person ’ s character. Advertising and stuff tells us that we have to be attractive. I think it ’ s wrong, but that ’ s the way the world is now.
column17: I ’ m afraid you ’ re right. I chose my girlfriend because she has a wonderful personality.
column18: Well, you certainly didn ’ t choose her because of her looks! Hey, I was joking! Don ’ t hit me!

column5: How long can I keep the books?
column6: For one month. If you can ’ t return the books in time, you'll be fined. But if you renew them, you can keep them longer.
column7: I see. Now I want to check out two books on spoken English. Can you show me where I can find them?
column8: Yes, just over there to your right.
column9: Thank you very much.
column10: You ’ re welcome.

column5: It always hurts. I hate going.

column8: Good. You'll feel better after you do.

column1: What happened? Why didn't he win ;

column6: He was taking steroids to make him stronger and faster.

column8: They are. The only reason they didn't disqualify him until after the race is because the results from the text only came back afterwards.
column9: That's so disappointing. I don't know why top athletes would feel the need to take drugs.
column10: I don't think it's right, but I can understand why they might. Imagine how much pressure there would be to win for your country!

column1: excuse me? How can I get to the nearest branch of the national bank?
column2: there ’ s branch on new street. Walk up this street until you get to the first set of traffic lights. Then turn right at the traffic lights.

column4: not far. About 150 meters perhaps.
column5: ok. So I turn right at the traffic lights. Then?
column6: then keep walking until you reach the war memorial. It ’ s a big statue of a soldier. You can ’ t miss it.
column7: ok. Where do I go then?
column8: you ’ ll see the national bank near the war memorial. It ’ s a big building and you ’ ll see a big sign on the front of the building.
column9: got it. Thank you very much.

column1: We can't go that way, the road is blocked for the next few days.

column5: I think that they get a pretty good payoff.
column6: The movie company has to pay them?
column7: I don't know about all of that, but think about it, their business gets free publicity!
column8: Oh, yeah, they get to be in a movie for the whole world to see!

column1: Hello there, welcome to Wine World. Let me know if I can help you out at all.
column2: Um, yes, please, I could really use some help. I'm going over to my boss'house for dinner tonight and don't know what kind of wine I should bring.
column3: OK, do you know what kind of food will be served?
column4: Well, his wife is Japanese. He said she makes really good sushi.
column5: Hmm, that's a bit of a challenge. Sushi is notoriously difficult to pair with wine. Well, let's see. have to be a white wine, of course.
column6: Why? Wouldn't a red wine go well with sushi?
column7: No, I don't think so. Sushi is a very delicately flavored food, and red wine would be a jarring contrast. You need a white wine, which has more subtle flavors, to complement the fish.
column8: I see. So should I get a bottle of Chardonnay? That's a white wine, right?
column9: Yes, Chardonnay is a white wine, but I'm not sure it'd be your best bet. Chardonnay is one of the more fullbodied whites, and tends to be a bit oaky. I'd suggest that you go for something brighter, like this Sauvignon Blanc from New Zealand.
column10: Sauvignon Blanc? What's that?
column11: That's another varietal, or type of grape, just like Chardonnay.
column12: Let's see. The label says it's got " attractive citrus and grassy aromas that give way to crisp, mineral flavors and a bonedry finish. Serve chilled. " Oh, no, how long will it take to chill the wine? I'm on my way to the dinner now.
column13: It's OK, don't worry, we'll just choose a wine from the cooler. We don't have quite as extensive a selection over here, but... this Rhone Valley white would be lovely.
column14: All right. What varietal is that?
column15: Well, this is a French wine, so they don't always specify the varietal on the label. The French believe that the soil a grape is grown in is one of the most important factors in the final flavor of the wine. This wine is probably a blend of a few different types of grapes, mostly Viognier, I'd guess.
column16: And you think this is a good wine?
column17: Yes, this is one of our best-sellers. It's not quite as dry as the Sauvignon Blanc we were looking at earlier, which means it's more approachable. It's light and crisp, with a bit of a vanilla aroma.
column18: Perfect! I'll take it!

column1: Excuse me, I'm looking for the airport bus stop. Do you know where it is?
column2: Here it is.
column3: When does the bus come?
column4: You just missed one.
column5: How about the next one?
column6: In an hour.
column7: Isn't there an earlier one?
column8: No, they come every hour on the hour.
column9: Thank you very much.
column10: You are welcome.

column1: If you can choose, will you marry a foreigner or a Chinese?
column2: Why? Did tom pop the question?
column3: Not yet. But I wonder if I can get my parents ’ consent.
column4: Let me guess, your parents want you to marry a Chinese man, right?
column5: You are right. It is giving me a real headache. I feel like I ’ m between a rock and a hard place.
column6: I used to have the same problem when I was with my ex.
column7: Oh, how did you deal with it?
column8: I just let it go and continued dating with my Korean boyfriend. But finally we broke up.
column9: Oh, it ’ s a pity. What was the matter?
column10: Simple. We had personality clashes and there were too many cultural differences.
column11: Like what?
column12: He hoped to live in the Korean way and asked me to give up working and stay at home to take care of the family.
column13: Oh, I see. In their culture women should put family first.
column14: Yes, he said it would be better for me and for the whole family. But I simply can not quit working.
column15: So that's why it ’ s hard to have a happy marriage with a foreigner.
column16: Not really. There are many successful mixed marriage around us.

column1: Wow, Is winter always this cold in Taiwan?
column2: Not really. It's much warmer usually. Your are not used to cold weather?
column3: No, I am from south California. This is my first real winter.
column4: Well, You'd better get some more warm clothes.
column5: What's the temperature today anyway?
column6: I would say it's about 5 degree Celsius.

column6: How about mileage and gas?

column8: OK. I'll try a Pinto. I want to rent a car for one week.

column10: Here you are.

column1: Mr. : There are two things that you'll need to know.
column2: What are they?

column4: Wow!
column5: Mr. : Furthermore, when you are dismissed in the afternoon, you will be divided into two waves.
column6: Two waves?
column7: Mr. : The school parking lot is not big enough for all the school buses to come in at one time. So only half the buses come in first to pick up the first wave's students.
column8: And the other half come in later to pick up the second wave.

column1: Thanks for inviting me to your friend ’ s wedding. I was surprised to hear the bride and groom talking to each other that way during the marriage ceremony. Is that common?
column2: Well, some people use a standard set of words, but many couples today write their own wedding vows.
column3: Your tradition of throwing rice as they got into their car was interesting, but it didn't look like real rice to me.
column4: It wasn't. It was birdseed. We don't throw rice anymore because someone discovered that birds come along and eat the rice and have trouble digesting it.
column5: Oh, I didn't think of that. Well, this reception reminds me of weddingparties back in China. Plenty of food and drink, music and dancing, and interesting traditions.
column6: Wait until you see what happens next! The bride is getting ready to throw her bouquet. Let's go over and watch.
column7: She ’ s got quite a crowd around her. Oh, look! That little girl caught it!
column8: She ’ s my friend ’ s ten-year-old niece. I guess there won ’ t be another wedding in this family for a long time.

column1: I am kind of nervous.
column2: Nervous? Why?
column3: I don't know. I never went to a church before. I was not raised as a Christian, so I don't know what to do.
column4: Don't worry. You don't have to do anything.All you have to do is listen. You will enjoy it.
column5: Maybe. I know I agreed to go with you, but now I don't feel right about it.
column6: Listen, Ryan.Catholics welcome people who aren't Catholics to visit the church.You don't have to pretend to be Catholic. It's okay if you just come to listen.
column7: Really?
column8: Yes. We are kind and welcoming people.It is not a secret society or something like that.
column9: Alright. But will we sing?
column10: Yes, but you don't even have to sing. If you want to sing along, you can.
column11: I don't know the words.
column12: There is a songbook. All the words are in the songbook.Many people have to read the words.
column13: And will I go up to the front to have the bread and wine?
column14: No. That is something only true Catholics do.So if you come to the church as a visitor, you only listen to the service.But you shouldn't go up to the altar for the bread and wine.Only after someone joins the church, then they go up for the Eucharist.
column15: Eu-char-ist? What is that?
column16: That is the special word for the ritual of the bread and wine.The Catholics call it the Eucharist.
column17: It doesn't sound like an English word.
column18: It's not. It's an ancient Greek word. It means gratitude.
column19: Alright. Well, I feel more comfortable now.Now I understand I am welcome as a visitor.
column20: Of course you are. I wouldn't ask you otherwise.

column1: I ’ m glad to have had the opportunity to meet you here.
column2: I trust you ’ re keeping well?
column3: I ’ m doing great, thank you.
column4: So we can get down to business.

column1: You are studying here, aren ’ t you?

column3: Do you like this campus?
column4: Well. I ’ m rather disappointed with it.
column5: How come?
column6: It ’ s too old. And it isn ’ t as specious as I expected.
column7: Oh. It ’ s awful, but it can ’ t be helped.
column8: I ’ ll just have to put up with it.

column1: I ’ m terribly sorry to cause you so much trouble.

column4: I washed my car instead.

column6: No I didn ’ t. I worked in the morning then I played tennis with my husband.

column4: I don't know... Hey, do you think I could borrow your car for a few hours?

column7: Sure. That's no problem.
column8: Oh, and Andy? Do you have a quarter for the phone? My wallet's in the car.
column9: Here you go. Anything else?
column10: No, that's it. Thanks. I really appreciate it.

column9: Let's leave then. I could take some fresh air, anyway.

column7: Let's see. there's my mom and dad and my two brothers and one of my sisters.

column3: Certainly. What kind of room would you like?
column4: A single room please. I hope you ’ re not fully booked.
column5: A single room? That ’ s fine. In whose name shall I make the booking?
column6: Jones. According to your website, the nightly rate is $ 50, including breakfast.
column7: We offer a 20 % discount for guests staying of Friday and Saturday. The total cost will be $ 80, including breakfast.
column8: Thank you very much. I look forward to seeing you on Friday.
column9: Could I just take your credit card number please? I should mention that there is a cancellation charge of $ 20.
column10: That ’ s fine. My credit card number is...

column1: Have you watched any of the talent shows on TV?
column2: Yes, I've watched the finale for the' Super Girl'. The producer is very smart to copy the program from the US, which is quite fresh and eye-catching for mainland audiences.
column3: Yeah, and they know exactly what the audiences have in mind. Everyone desires equal opportunities and a channel to climb up the social ladder all the way to the highest in society.
column4: That' s why the program has attracted so many star-wanna-bes.
column5: But it seems that these talent shows are getting less popular these days. There's no such program on this year.
column6: Yeah, these programs are gradually losing their appeal.
column7: No surprise. The over-the-top promotion has ruined the audiences' appetite.
column8: And they lack originality. Talent shows like' Super Girl' and' Super Boy' are largely clones of' The American Idol'.
column9: The same is true for' My Hero'. Winners of the contest used to star in the TV series' The Frog Prince'.
column10: I think producers are underestimating the audience. They should think of better ways to entertain the general public.

column1: Can I have this roll of film developed here?
column2: Sure. Let's see it.
column3: Here you are.
column4: What size of prints would you like to have?
column5: Regular will be fine. How long will it take?
column6: Only four hours.
column7: Good. I'll come back in the evening.

column1: Do you know how happy I am? The Ant Kingdom is a perfect world with colorful fairy tales. It seems like the air is fresh here.

column5: I said you are sure to like them. There is the Grand Parade Of Ants Carnival in a few minutes in the square. You will experience a dream of fantasy.
column6: What's that?
column7: All kinds of insects dress themselves up. They drive straight their own Flower Cars along the Parade Avenue of Ants Kingdom.
column8: That's splendid. Can you take three pictures of me with them?
column9: I thought you had grown out of such child practices.
column10: Cut it out. Look at my smile, and it seems like the flowers in the spring. Right?
column11: Gross!
column12: Hurry up! The smile is frozen on my face.

column10: Okay, sir, but don't think too long. Your checkout is only 30 minutes away.

column3: Don't you think it' s a sheer waste of both time and money?
column4: I'm afraid not. Every coin has two sides. I think using internet has a great deal to do with human interaction.

column1: Hello. I am calling about the apartment you advertised.

column4: Yes, I have one. When you need it?
column5: Sometime around next week. What can you tell me about this apartment?
column6: Well, It's a one-bedroom apartment. The monthly rent at 650 dollars and a 300 dollars security deposit. You pay electricity only. Gas and water is included. Both the heat and stove are gas. Let me see, what else... Oh, you'll be assigned a sheltered parking space at no extra charge. And that's probably it.
column7: Sounds good. May I come over tomorrow to take a look?
column8: Sure. What time would you like to come?
column9: How about 10 am?
column10: Good, May I have your name, please?
column11: My name is Blanca.

column1: Next please! Hello sir, may I see your passport please?
column2: Yes, here you go.
column3: Will you be checking any bags today.
column4: Yes, I ’ d like to check three pieces.
column5: I ’ m sorry, sir. Airline policy allows only two pieces of checked luggage, at twenty kilograms each, plus one piece of carry-on luggage. I will have to charge you extra for the additional suitcase.
column6: What? Why! I am taking an intercontinental flight! I ’ m flying sixteen thousand CMS! How am I supposed to only take two, twenty kilo bags? That ’ absurd!
column7: I am sorry, sir, there ’ s nothing I can do. You cannot board the flight with that large bag either.Carry - on bags must fit in the over-head compartment or under your seat. That bag is clearly too big.
column8: Now I see. You charge next to nothing for an international ticket, but when it comes to charging for any other small thing, you charge an arm and a leg! So tell me, miss, how much will I have to pay for all of this.
column9: Let ’ s see... six hundred and twenty-five US dollars.
column10: That ’ s more than my round-trip ticket!

column1: Hi, John.

column6: Oh, well, that might be a problem. I usually only sign one year leases.
column7: Well, one year would be fine, too. I ’ m not planning on leaving the area anytime soon.
column8: Well, if it ’ s not a problem. Then here you go.
column9: Just let me look at it quickly.
column10: Of course.
column11: Looks like a standard lease.
column12: Yeah, and don ’ t worry about the security deposit. If everything ’ s all right when you move out, you ’ ll get it back.
column13: O. K. Great. Just sign and date it here?
column14: Yes. Thanks. You can move your stuff in tomorrow.
column15: Wonderful.

column1: Where ’ s the wagon?
column2: Where ’ s what wagon?
column3: The water wagon.
column4: What water wagon?
column5: The wagon with the water, of course.
column6: That ’ s my wagon. I need the water to water my flowers in the yard.
column7: No, you can ’ t do that. There isn ’ t much water in the wagon. And we need the water for drinking.

column1: May, look, what's that in the cage ;
column2: Please visit t.cn.
column3: Of course I know. I just can't see it very well.
column4: OK, then put on your glasses, and do you know what does the panda eat?
column5: Of course, Bamboo!
column6: That's right.
column7: I also know they are given to other countries as gifts for friendship.
column8: You sound quite knowledgeable.
column9: Not really, panda is my favorite animal.
column10: Actually, it likes milk too.

column1: OK, Mr. Wang. Thank you very much for coming to the airport to see us off. Your great country and your hospitality have left a very deep impression on all of us and your working attitude and your way of doing business have changed my opinions about Chinese people.
column2: Really? I'm glad to hear that.
column3: That's true. And this trip has been a very productive one for us.
column4: Thank you again for your visit. We are looking forward to your reply.
column5: Believe me, Mr. Wang. I'll do my best to promote the transaction.
column6: We are happy that we have established business relations. I really hope that we'll have more business to do and more opportunities to meet each other.
column7: It ’ s very kind of you to say so.
column8: You are very nice and helpful. Hope to see you again.
column9: I think we will have opportunities to meet each other in the future.
column10: OK, I think it's time for you to check in. If you run into any difficulty, we'll be here to assist you immediately.
column11: Fine. Thank you very much. Bye-bye.
column12: Goodbye.

column1: How was the movie last night?
column2: I didn't really like it.
column3: Mary said that she was really pleased with the photography.
column4: I found it very disappointing.
column5: She liked the acting, too, because that's what she wanted to see.
column6: I wasn't happy with it.
column7: Nothing is to your satisfaction.

column1: Excuse me. Nature calls.
column2: If you gotta go, you gotta go.

column1: I wonder if it is possible that we organize a dinner party for all the colleagues in our departments. They are working very hard these days. Maybe it is time for everybody to relax a little.
column2: That is a good idea, I love it. What time do you think is convenient?
column3: Well, what about this Thursday evening after we finish the weekly meeting?
column4: Ok, I will inform everybody when they come back from lunch. It has been a long time since we had the department dinner last time. I am sure they don ’ t want to miss it.
column5: I hope so. Let me know how many will come. Then I will book the restaurant.

column1: I heard many stories about your brother.
column2: He's a hero in our town.
column3: What does he look like? Is he handsome?
column4: Yes, indeed, People say he's the smartest young man.

column1: Happy New Year, Bill.
column2: Happy New Year, Steven.
column3: Do you have any plans for the New Year holiday?
column4: My whole family are going to Hainan for visiting. What about you?
column5: How happy you are! I have to stay at home to prepare my final exam.

column1: To which gate do I need to go to catch connecting flight 707 to New York City?
column2: Go to Gate 56, the plane is now boarding, you must hurry.
column3: Show me the fastest way to get there.
column4: Instead of walking you can take this shuttle to get you there faster.
column5: Do you think the plane will leave without me?
column6: No, I will call the attendants at the gate. I'll tell them you are on your way.
column7: Thank you so much, I would really appreciate that.
column8: You're welcome, have a safe trip.

column2: Andrew, this is Linda Chen.
column3: Hi Linda, what can I do for you?
column4: I need to set up an appointment to get my hair fixed.
column5: For what day?
column6: Tuesday morning.

column1: Hello!
column2: Is that Sue?
column3: Speaking.
column4: A.This is George.
column5: Hello, George.What' s up?

column1: May I speak to Peter?
column2: Who's calling?

column1: It's a sunny day, isn't it?
column2: Yes, it is. I'm Jennifer. Nice to meet you.
column3: My name is David. Nice to meet you, too.
column4: Are you American?
column5: No, I'm a Britisher. Where do you come from?
column6: I come from America. Are you a freshman?
column7: Yes. What about you?
column8: Me, too.
column9: Great. Maybe we can study and play games together. I think we can be good friends.
column10: Yeah. Anytime.

column1: Hi ;
column2: Hi, Mary, Hi, Ken I hate to bring this up, but that new stereo, system you got...
column3: Yeah?
column4: You were playing it very late last night.
column5: Yeah?
column6: It kept me awake.
column7: Oh, I'm sorry.
column8: It kept me awake a couple of hours.
column9: I'm so sorry, I.. I didn't realize it was that loud.
column10: It was that loud, and it was pretty late, and check with Mary if you don't believe me.

column1: What is the proper way to handle a napkin at dinner?
column2: Ordinarily, as soon as you are seated, you put your napkin on your lap.
column3: How about at a formal dinner?
column4: At a formal dinner, you wait for your hostess to put hers on her lap first.

column1: Hey, Mike, is Jenny coming with us ;
column2: Yes. Why?
column3: Nothing. I'm just asking.
column4: Just asking? But why is your face burning like mad? Ah-huh, someone has a crush on Jenny, doesn't he?
column5: Who has a crush?!
column6: Come on, Ted, don't be such a chicken. If you like her, you've got to tell her. Maybe she likes you.
column7: Well, I don't have the guts to ask her out.
column8: What're you so afraid of? Just tell her what you're feeling about her.
column9: I'd totally die if she turned me down.
column10: But that's better than keeping everything to yourself. You've got to let her know. Come on! You've got to take a chance! Even though you are rejected, it's not the end of the world! There's nothing to lose, is there?

column1: Does Mr. Schmidt know he's going to become a father?
column2: No, and I have no way of getting ahold of him! There's no phone where he's at!
column3: Well, he has a surprise waiting for him when he gets back, doesn't he!
column4: My older sister Judy will be here soon to help. She already has a boy and a girl of her own...
column5: I just saw a red van pulling into the driveway. Is that her?

column1: I'm looking for some fresh produce that's on sale.
column2: Well, we just got in some mangoes.
column3: Mangoes. What are they?
column4: Well, it's a fruit with a big nut in it.
column5: Can you eat the nut?
column6: No, you peel off the skin and throw out the nut.
column7: How much are they?
column8: Well, the sale price is $ 1 each.
column9: What does a mango taste like?
column10: They're like a citrus fruit.
column11: How do I know if it's ripe?
column12: You can buy them hard. Wait a few days for them to develop a soft feel.
column13: Where do they come from?
column14: Most of them in this store are from Mexico.

column1: I can ’ t find my purse. Have you seen it?
column2: No, I haven ’ t.
column3: I ’ Ve looked everywhere for it. I must have left it somewhere. I hope I haven ’ t lost it.
column4: Perhaps you left that at school.
column5: No, I had it when I left school this afternoon.
column6: Well. Didn ’ t you go around to the Smith after school? You might have left it there.
column7: Yes, I ’ d better give her a call now.
column8: But she can ’ t be home now. She might have gone to the library.
column9: Perhaps I should call her later.

column1: Would you show me some table-cloths?
column2: Certainly. ( Take a table-cloth to her )
column3: How much is it?
column4: A table-cloth of this size and style is 15 Yuan.
column5: That ’ s reasonable.
column6: If you take good care of it, it will last you quite a number of years.
column7: Really? I ’ ll take it then.

column1: Freeze! Police! Put your hands over your head!
column2: What did I do? I haven't done anything.
column3: You're under arrest for concealing illegal drugs.
column4: What do you mean?
column5: You are suspected of hiding illegal drugs. So we are taking you into custody.
column6: I didn't do anything.
column7: We've found some heroin at your house.
column8: No, I didn't. I'm innocent. Those aren't mine. Whatever you found is someone else's stuff. You can't prove anything. I wasn't there when you went in, and you can't prove it's my stuff.
column9: That may be, but you're still under arrest. And you'd better stop talking.
column10: I don't need your help, jerk.
column11: Whatever you say.

column1: I'm planning on going to the market soon.
column2: What are you buying?
column3: I don't know what we need.
column4: I can check for you, if you'd like.
column5: I'll make a list.
column6: First, we need eggs, milk, and bread.
column7: OK! Do we need any meat?
column8: How about some chicken, ground beef, and some steak.
column9: What else do we need?
column10: Get some snack foods, too, dude.
column11: Is there anything else that we need?
column12: No, but if you can think of anything else, just get it.

column1: Will you have time this Saturday evening to go to the cinema with me?
column2: Saturday? Oh, I have a previous engagement.
column3: What a pity! Then how about Sunday?
column4: I've already got plans, too.
column5: Then when do you think we could go out together?
column6: How about Friday? Only in that day can I arrange it.
column7: OK. Any time on Friday will be OK with me.
column8: That's settled then. I'll contact you later.

column1: You know John?
column2: Which John? Mr.Turnbow ’ s son?
column3: Yes. I ’ Ve read news about him in today ’ s paper.
column4: And he ’ s bright and intelligent. I ’ m sure he can pass the university entrance exam.
column5: I wish he could too.
column6: How ’ s your boy, Jack?
column7: He ’ s a bit tired, you know. It often takes him a couple of hours to brush up.
column8: Poor boys! They work harder at school nowadays, don ’ t they?
column9: Good luck to them.

column1: My child is often absent-minded in class.
column2: It's all right. Kids are like that.
column3: But if he doesn't listen to the teacher carefully, he won't learn anything.
column4: Don't worry. His teacher will tell him to be good.
column5: I hope so.

column1: My disposable contact lenses. They're great for camping!
column2: Cool! Each contact comes in its own saline solution?
column3: Yep. They're prescription contacts with UV protection.
column4: Wow! How high-class... a new pair for each day...
column5: You just pop'em in in the morning, take them out at night, and then throw them away. No cleaning!
column6: Cool. So are you near-sighted or far-sighted?
column7: Near sighted.

column1: Oh. Henry. I haven't seen you in ages. Come in. Let me take your coat. How are you getting along ;
column2: Very well, thank you.
column3: Please take a seat. Everything will be ready in a minute.
column4: Here you go. We have your cocktail and there're salad. fried chicken, French fries and vanilla ice cream for dessert. Eat the chicken while it's hot. It tastes better.
column5: Wow! You're right. Everything is absolutely delicious. Please pass the pepper.
column6: Here you are. Taste the French fries.
column7: They're soft.
column8: Would you like some more?
column9: No more. Thank you.
column10: Here's to our friendship and health!

column1: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
column2: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
column3: Blow my nose?
column4: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
column5: No, please, Mom! Don't make me gargle with saltwater!
column6: It works better than any medicine, Lily. I'll make you a glass right now, and you'll finish it!

column1: Good morning, Passport, please.
column2: Here you are.
column3: Ah, thank you.Please bring your luggage here for inspection.
column4: Ok.But is there anything wrong?
column5: It's just a regular inspection.Do you have anything to declare?
column6: I've got 6 packets of cigarettes and 2 bottles of champagne.Besides, I have two cameras, one is for my own use, and the other is a gift.
column7: Well, the cigarettes and the champagne are not in excess of the duty-free allowance. But according to our law, each passenger is allowed only one camera duty-free.You' ll have to pay duty for the other one.
column8: Ok. Where shall I pay duty for it?
column9: Please wait a minute. I'll make out the duty memo... Here you are.Take this and pay to the woman over there.
column10: I've paid for it. Here's the receipt.
column11: Very well. I hope you' ll enjoy your stay in America.
column12: Thank you.

column1: Can you help me set up my voicemail message? I just got this service and I am not really sure what I am supposed to say.
column2: Sure! You just basically gotta let the caller know who they called, and ask them for their contact information so you can call them back.
column3: Ok, so can I say, " This is Abby's voicemail. I will call you later, so leave me your name and number ".
column4: That's more or less the idea, but try something that sounds more friendly.
column5: Ok, so how about this, " This is Abby and I am really happy you called! I promise I will give you a ring as soon as I can, so please leave me your name and number. Talk to you soon! ".
column6: A little too friendly Abby. Just say this, " Hi, you have reached Abby. I am unable to answer your call right now, but if you leave me your name and phone number, I will get back to you as soon as possible. Thanks ".
column7: That's perfect! Can you say that again and record it for me?

column1: How much is the postage for this postcard to China?
column2: How would you like to send it?
column3: By airmail.
column4: Sixty cents please.
column5: Here you are.
column6: Please write down the zip code in the mailing address.
column7: Oh, one more thing, I want to send the card by registered mail too.
column8: OK. please give me twenty cents.
column9: Here it is. and thank you very much.
column10: You're welcome.

column1: What ’ s the life expectancy in your country?
column2: I ’ m not sure, but probably about 75 years. How about in your country?
column3: About 70, I think. This newspaper article talks about the problems of an aging population. It ’ s a problem that will soon affect most of the world.
column4: I heard that the government might need to increase the retirement age, because otherwise there will not be enough workers to support the young and the elderly.
column5: Perhaps we need to have more babies! Tina gave birth to a baby boy yesterday.
column6: Did she? That ’ s great. However, if we have too many children, that will have a bad effect on the enviroment.
column7: How ’ s your son these days?
column8: Oh, he ’ s fine. Kids seem to grow up very quickly nowadays.
column9: He ’ ll be a teenager before you know it! Teenagers are often rebellious! When do you mine it is a good age to have a child?
column10: I had mine when I was 24. that ’ s a little young. I ’ d suggest you wait until you are in your late twenties., or even in your early thirties if you have a good career.
column11: Yes, I think you ’ re right. I ’ m thinking about having a child, but not just yet.
column12: Is there a big generation gap between parents and their children in you country?
column13: Yes, there is. Teenagers do not want to live traditional lives. They want to go out, have fun, and explore the world. They want to develop their own view of life. Parents usually try to discourage them, but they don ’ t often succeed.
column14: Parents usually give their children more freedom in my country. Sometimes they give them too much freedom.
column15: It ’ s almost impossible to get the right balance. If you are too strict, kids might ignore you. If you are too lenient, they might go wild.

column1: how do you usually spend your day, now that you ’ Ve retired?
column2: well, I nearly always get up at dawn. I don ’ t like sleeping in late. The days are longer in summer that in winter, so I get up in summer. I usually do some exercise when I get up.
column3: what do you have for breakfast?
column4: I usually have cereal, but sometimes I cook a traditional English breakfast.
column5: that sounds nice. How do you spend your mornings?
column6: I usually do housework in mornings. I go shopping occasionally. I like to do all my shopping in one bag trip to the supermarket. I always drive to the big supermarket in the city center. It takes about
column7: how do you spend your afternoons?
column8: I usually meet some friends and we play sports together or I might spend some time alone on my hobbies. I spend winter evening watching tv, but I spend summer evening at cultural events if I have time

column1: Hello, my name is Xu Hua. I'm from Beijing.
column2: Hello, Xu Hua. I'm Paula. I'm American.
column3: Welcome to China, Paula.
column4: Thank you.

column1: Hello, Jason, there is going to be a screening of Final Destination 3 at our campus cinema tomorrow. I plan to go to see it.
column2: Is it a horror movie?
column3: Yeah, I love horror movies. Would you like to go with me tomorrow?
column4: No way. I will be scared out of my wits.
column5: That's funny, I didn't know a big fellow like you could be so soft and timid on the inside.
column6: Hey, how would you like to taste my fist?
column7: Alright, all joking aside, what kinds of moves do you like?
column8: Um, let me see, romance, comedy. documentary, action, science fiction, animated and so on.
column9: That is to say, you like all genres except for horror movies.
column10: Yeah. It seems like we don't speak the same language as far as movies are concerned.
column11: Not quite. I also greatly enjoy romance and comedy.
column12: The Notebook is this type of movie.
column13: Really? I haven't heard of it.
column14: Well then, this could be a nice opportunity to enjoy it together. I bet you'd love it.
column15: Ok. I can't wait to see it. Let's go!

column1: What are we going to eat for dinner ;
column2: Are you going to cook anything?
column3: I didn't plan on cooking tonight.
column4: If you're hungry, then cook something.
column5: I don't know what to make.
column6: Tell me what you want to eat.
column7: I've been craving chicken and potatoes.
column8: I'd like that.
column9: Are you going to cook it tonight?
column10: I'm really not going to cook tonight.

column1: Rose, the weekend is coming. Let's discuss what we will do.
column2: What about going to the zoo on Saturday and to the park on Sunday?
column3: Sounds good. But on Saturday there's a football final.
column4: Then, what shall we do on Sunday.
column5: Let me see. We can visit the country. We haven't done that for such a long time.
column6: Good idea. I'll go shopping in one of the department stores nearby. We'll go to the zoo and the park another time. After all, we can put that off.
column7: OK.

column1: Hello, could I make a reservation?
column2: Sure. At what time?
column3: 6 o'dock in the evening.
column4: Let me see... Sorry, sir. We are fully booked tonight. Would you mind making a reservation some other time?
column5: Do you offer mutton hot pot at noon?
column6: Yes, sir.
column7: Then we will come here for lunch tomorrow.

column1: Waiter, get me rag, please. I have just spilled my wine.
column2: Let me help you.
column3: Thank you. Please bring me some paper napkins.
column4: Here you are.
column5: I think I should be more careful next time.

column1: Honey, we are all out of wine and cheese. Do you mind running to the deli and picking up a few things?
column2: Can ’ t it wait? I ’ m watching the game right now!
column3: Your friends and family are coming over tonight and we still need to get a lot of things.
column4: Fine! What do you need?
column5: OK, pick up some cured meats to go with the wine. Maybe a pound of polish sausages, ham, liverwurst, salami and any other cold cuts that are on sale. I think I saw a promotion for pastrami. Also get some cole slaw and a jar of olives.
column6: Whoa wait a minute! Isn ’ t that a bit too much? I mean, how much is all of this going to cost!
column7: Never mind that. Get some dips as well. Get a jar of spinach and blue cheese dip and also some Tzatziki. If they have bean dip get that as well. Last but not least, get some pickles.
column8: Is that all, your majesty?
column9: Very funny! Get a move on! People will be here any minute.

column1: Can I have this shoe in the black please?
column2: Of course, sir, I'll have a look in the back.
column3: Okay.
column4: I'm afraid I haven't got one in your size.

column1: I'm going to the park to play baseball with the guys.
column2: But you promised to play chess with me this afternoon.
column3: Yeah, but that was before the guys ask me to join the team.
column4: So what?
column5: You know how much I want to be on the team, and now there is an opening for me.If I don't go to practise today.They' ll get someone else and I'll miss my chance.
column6: I don't care about baseball.You know I need to practice for the chess championship and you promised to help with me if I washed the dishes for you last Sunday, and I did.
column7: I know, and I will.
column8: When?
column9: After baseball practice.
column10: And then, it'll be dinner time, then homework, and then your Show is on.You are going to break your promise.
column11: No, I won't. I'm going to skip TV tonight and work on your chess game with you if that's ok with you.
column12: Well, I'd rather do it the way we set up.But if you promise to give me your best game, it's ok with me.
column13: No problem, I'll play as hard as I can and give you an extra game to say thanks.

column1: good morning. I understand that you ’ Ve got a problem with your washing machine. I ’ m from the repair company.
column2: excellent. Come in please. The washing machine is in the bathroom upstairs. It keeps breaking down.
column3: when did it first break down?
column4: about ten days ago. I ’ Ve tried to use it since then. Sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn ’ t. it ’ s very frustrating.
column5: is it still under warranty. If it is and I can ’ t fix it, it would be quicker and easier to exchange it for a new one.
column6: yes, it ’ s still under warranty. Over the last few weeks, it ’ s also been making a high - pitch noise when it ’ s in use.
column7: ok. I ’ ll start by looking at the motor. I ’ ll just unplug it and take a look inside the machine... oh, yes. There ’ s the problem. It ’ s quite simple. I ’ ll sort it out in a few minutes.
column8: what ’ s wrong with it?
column9: part of the motor is loose. I can put it back in place quite easily.
column10: that ’ s great. Thanks very much. Would you like a cup of tea or coffee?

column1: Excuse me, you look lost. Can I help you?
column2: Oh, Thank you. I'm looking for the train station.
column3: Right. Let me see. You go straight down here and turn right.
column4: Right? OK, got it.
column5: Then take the next left then the next right. Are you with me?
column6: Next left then right? OK.

column1: Could you show me my bill?
column2: Here you are.That comes to 120 yuan.
column3: Can I have it charged to my account, please?
column4: Certainly, sir.Would you sign here, please?... Thank you.

column1: Good, morning! Can I help you?
column2: Good morning.Could you tell me the times of trains to London, please?
column3: Yes.There are trains at seven fifty-nine, nine eighteen, ten thirty-two and eleven fifty-five.
column4: What time does the seven fifty-nine get to London?
column5: At nine thirty-six.And the nine eighteen gets to London at nine fifty-five, the ten thirty-two at eleven nine.
column6: What about coming back? I'd like to come back about 7 p. m.
column7: There's one at nineteen and the next is at nineteen forty.
column8: Mmm, how much is it?
column9: Single or return?
column10: Return, please.

column1: Welcome, sir. What can I do for you?
column2: May I have a look at that china tea set? It is extremely beautiful.
column3: You've made a good choice. This china tea set is unusual. It was made in Jingdezhen.
column4: Jingdezhen? Oh, I know it. Isn't it called the capital of porcelain?
column5: Yes, sir.
column6: Oh, it must be very precious. Is it breakable?
column7: No, if you take some care when you use them.
column8: How much is it?
column9: Two thousand.
column10: Oh, it is beyond my purse.

column1: Can you give me a hand with some things in the kitchen? I don ’ t think I can finish everything in time.
column2: Ok, what do you want me to do?
column3: First of all, I need you to do the drying up. I ’ m almost finished the washing up. I ’ m going to clean the cooker when I finish.
column4: Ok. I ’ ll put the plates and cutlery away as I dry them. Where is the tea towel? Oh, here it is.
column5: We ’ ll have this finished in no time with two if us working on it.
column6: While you ’ re cleaning the cooker, I ’ ll wipe the worktop. That was a great meat, by the way.
column7: Actually, it was just some leftovers from yesterday. I made far too much food to eat alone. I am glad you could come over to help me finish it.
column8: My pleasure! This tea towel ’ s a little ragged. Do you have another one?
column9: Yes. Look in that drawer. I should throw the old one out.
column10: Keep it and use it as rag. You can clean your bicycle with it.

column4: Well, two big suitcases and two small bags.
column5: I'll send someone up right away.

column3: With everything on it?
column4: That sounds great.
column5: Did you want fries with your order?
column6: May I get a large order of curly fries?
column7: Did you want something to drink?
column8: Get me a medium Pepsi.
column9: Would you like anything else?
column10: No, thank you. That's it.

column3: It's easy, let me help you.
column4: Great, thanks a lot.

column1: Hey, your Chinese is coming along!
column2: You think?
column3: Yeah. It ’ s a lot better than mine.
column4: But I still get stuck on the different tones.It drives me crazy.
column5: Hang in there. It ’ ll all come together one of these days.

column1: Have you found a new job yet?
column2: No, not yet. I ’ m still looking. I ’ Ve been doing some work through a temp-agency though.

column4: I ’ m temping at a pharmaceutic company.

column1: Excuse me, I ’ Ve been waiting my main dish for quite a time.

column1: Do you think children watch too much Tv?

column6: ZZZ means'sleepy or tired or bored', A / S / L is tricky, which is often used at first encounter. It's a three-word question,' age, / sex / location?'
column7: Interesting. Then what does H & K refer to? The city of Hong Kong?
column8: Wrong. lt's not a place name, but a passionate act.
column9: Really? What kind? A girl left this word to me, and I thought she was in Hong Kong.
column10: Ahahah... you miss her point for sure. H & K actually is an acronym for' hug and kiss'.

column1: Alright everyone settle down. Let ’ s get started.As you know, an important aspect of becoming a good citizen is understanding the genesis of our legal system. It is not enough to simply memorize our laws, it is necessary that we comprehend why and how they were formed. This brings me to our topic for today. Does anyone know what we celebrate on May first ;
column2: Cinct de mayo?
column3: No, that ’ s May fifth in Spanish, James, no wonder you are failing my Spanish class. No, May first is International Workers ’ Day.
column4: Do we get a day off from school then?
column5: No! It is not considered to be a national holiday here in the US, but in other countries it is.
column6: Www, man!
column7: In the nineteenth century, working conditions were appalling, with workers being forced to work ten, twelve, and fourteen hours a day. Support for the eight-hour work day movement was growing rapidly, despite the indifference and hostility of many union leaders, and by April 1886, 250,000 workers were involved in the May Day movement.Previous legislative attempts to improve working conditions had failed, so labor organizers took drastic measures. They passed a resolution stating that eight hours would constitute a legal day ’ s work. And, on May First 1886, the resolution took effect.
column8: Cool! Is that why we only work eight hours now?
column9: Yes! But the happy ending came at a high price.On May third, 1886, police fired into a crowd of strikers at the McCormick Reaper Works Factory, killing four and wounding many. A mass meeting was called for the next day to protest the brutality.
column10: And then what happened?

column1: What's the weather like in your city?

column7: We do have a few foggy days in winter.but i would not say we have a lot of fogs.the sky are usually clearly over your city, are they?

column12: As you know, my city is on the coast.the water is also not clean.but people still go swimming all year around. i prefer to sand bath on the beach when the weather is hot in sunny.

column1: Hey, look at the offer I got in my e-mail. It says that I can get rich quickly while working at home!
column2: Do you also believe in Santa Claus and the Tooth Fairy?
column3: What do you mean?
column4: I mean that you're gullible. You shouldn't believe everything you read, especially on the Internet.
column5: But it seems like a good idea. All I have to do is first send some money to the person who sent me the letter. After that he'll tell me how to earn much more money.
column6: Sounds like a pyramid scheme. Have you heard of those before?
column7: Pyramid scheme? What is that?
column8: It's a scam 7 that's based on a hierarchy, like a pyramid. The person at the top asks the people below him for money, and then tells them to go and ask other people for money while sending some of it back to him.
column9: Sounds good to me. The guy at the top gets money and so do the people below him.
column10: Not exactly. The scam keeps on going, with the people at the bottom paying more and more money until they reach the very bottom.
column11: What happens then?
column12: Nothing. The people at the bottom give their money to the people above them, and they get nothing. They end up losing. That's why it's a scam.
column13: I see. I guess I should be more careful about what I read, especially on the Internet where you have no idea who anybody is.

column1: I think that show biz stars have a really easy life. They have lots of money, so they can buy almost anything they want. They ’ re famous, so everyone loves them.

column6: Show biz stars have plenty of expenses. That ’ s why they need so much money. They need million of dollars to buy big, seclude houses and wonderful dresses. I bet most show biz stars would prefer to wear jeans and a t-shirt, but they can ’ t because their managers force them to wear clothes they don ’ t like.
column7: I don ’ t understand how you can have any sympathy for show biz stars. They ’ re overpaid, over-ambitious, and over-adored.
